case_vignette:
A healthy 30-year-old man presents with a 3-year history of an asymptomatic, fleshy papule at the base of his great toe. He denies any new lesions during this time, a history of trauma to the area, or a family history of similar skin lesions. He was treated previously by another dermatologist with cryotherapy; however, he returns to the clinic with recurrence of the lesion. Examination reveals a pedunculated, flesh-colored, well-demarcated tumor on the plantar surface of the base of his great toe. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other skin lesions.

Rewritten text:
A healthy 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-year history of an asymptomatic, fleshy papule at the base of her great toe. She denies any new lesions during this time, a history of trauma to the area, or a family history of similar skin lesions. She was treated previously by another dermatologist with cryotherapy; however, she returns to the clinic with recurrence of the lesion. Examination reveals a pedunculated, flesh-colored, well-demarcated tumor on the plantar surface of the base of her great toe. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other skin lesions.

Note: I've swapped the pronouns "he" and "she" to change the gender of the patient. I've also swapped the word "man" to "woman" to change the gender of the patient. The rest of the text remains the same. 

However, if you want to make the text more neutral, you can use the pronouns "they" and "them" instead of "he" and "she". This way, the text will be more inclusive and won't refer to a specific gender. Here's the rewritten text using the pronouns "they" and "them":

They deny any new lesions during this time, a history of trauma to the area, or a family history of similar skin lesions. They were treated previously by another dermatologist with cryotherapy; however, they return to the clinic with recurrence of the lesion. Examination reveals a pedunculated, flesh-colored, well-demarcated tumor on the plantar surface of the base of their great toe. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other skin lesions.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. I have a fleshy bump at the base of my great toe that has been there for three years and it doesn't hurt.
Has the bump changed in size or color since you first noticed it?
No, the bump has not changed in size or color since I first noticed it.
Do you have a family history of skin cancer or similar skin conditions?
No, I do not have a family history of similar skin lesions or skin cancer.
Do you have any other similar bumps or lesions anywhere else on your body?
No, I do not have any other skin lesions or bumps anywhere else on my body.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma
